verb.description: Say something in answer to a remark or accusation, typically in a sharp, angry, or wittily incisive manner.
examples: “No need to be rude,” retorted Isabel
he retorted that this was nonsense
I resisted the urge to retort
it was now his time to retort the humiliation

noun.description: A sharp, angry, or wittily incisive reply to a remark.
examples: she opened her mouth to make a suitably cutting retort

origin: Early 16th century: from French retorte, from medieval Latin retorta, feminine past participle of retorquere twist back (with reference to the long recurved neck of the laboratory container).
